Delphic oracle, the.translation[0].defin: a temple (=a holy building) in Delphi in ancient Greece where a priestess gave answers from the god Apollo to questions people asked him. The answer was often in the form of a mysterious riddle (=a deliberately confusing question with a clever answer). Someone who is a respected authority on a particular subject is sometimes called a Delphic oracle
Mrs Thatcher was regarded as the Delphic oracle of modern conservatism.
